P. Corssen¹ thought that Posidonius was marked out as the source for the entire book by the many facts which we know with regard to the views of Posidonius, and by the predominance of Stoic lore throughout the book.

Rudolf Hirzel² thought the Stoic views so vague and general that Cicero could have developed them himself, that much that coincides with Posidonius⁷ known views may be common property of all philo- sopher83 that Cicero's work throughout is that of a Scepffic, and that he must have had the work of a Sceptic before him ; and that the style of the scepticism displayed points to Philo. ⁴

But he thinks that in ἐξ 26—49 some views derived from other systems are intermixed with Stoic material, and that in {g 50-81 Stoic doctrines are intermixed with material mainly drawn from Plato.

He thinks it clear from ἐξ 42 and 78 that Cicero had the work of Panaetius before him. For {g 82-94 he takes Crantor περὶ Πέιιθους to be the source3 for {g 97—99 Plato's Apologia 40 c foll.3 for §g 102—108 Chrysippus.

O. Heine5 thinks it certain that a Stoic work is the source for ἐξ 26-81. He rightly finds little trace of scepfficism, while the argu- ments throughout have a Stoic colouring. He notices the argument from the consensus gentium as specially valued by the Stoics, and the doctrine that the soul consists of the finest particles and there- fore ascends at death to the aether, which is similar in nature, as purely Stoic. He notes the Stoic view of the three powers of the soul (natura, sensus, ratio) (ξ 56) as found also in De [Vatum Deorum ii 12, 33 where it is probably to be referred to Posidonius.
